text: I think as soon as you start writing
down anything important whether it's for
example we have cuneiform encryption of
pottery glazes we have financial
transactions encrypted we have ancient
Greek encryption so the ancient Hebrew
texts have have codes in them the Karma
Sutra had an encryption recipe that
women were supposed to learn in order to
encrypt their their love letters so as
soon as you've got something precious to
hide then someone else is going to want
to steal it so you encrypt it eventually
they work out how to crack your
encryption so then you have to come up
with a better form of encryption and
that carries on for 2,000 years and
we've been chasing our tail like that
ever since yeah is there a point at
which we really get to somewhere where
there is this sort of quantum leap in
how good well we're able to do this I
think the the key stages are first of
all the kind of code we might use at
school where we substitute a letter for
a symbol so a becomes a diamond B
becomes a cross and so on and uses about
the extent of my understanding of
cryptography I was just actually I just
organized a bachelor party weekend for
my brother and I didn't want to tell him
where it was we were going to Munich so
I sent him an email with like a letter
number corresponds like Josh I got that
in a second it was like the number to
let out well for 1,500 years people
couldn't crack that kind of code and
eventually was cracked in Baghdad a
mathematician philosopher called al
Kindi noticed kind of it's fairly
obvious to us today that some letters
are more common than others in English
is the most common letter followed by T
followed by a so if I replace e with a
diamond then you'll see there are lots
of diamonds in the text you'll realize
it diameters an e so then you have to
start getting more complicated then you
have to start saying well how am I going
to fool this this this frequency
analysis
